Name: Web Design Therapy
title: Web Design Therapy
description: Web Design Development Agency business advice
body:
Web Design Therapy

Web Design Development Agency business advice
author: Chris Love
abstract: Web Design Development Agency business advice

episodes.title: Episode 3 - Hiring, being busy and how to raise prices
episodes.description:
1. Do you guys do retainer work? How do you upsell the benefit of being on a retainer?

2. What are some practical things for ensuring that you hire the right people for your agency?

3. How do you manage to balance growth? Were you successful in growing inbound leads/clients first, then focused on growing your team, the other way around, or a 50/50 split?

4. What's your favourite website?

5. Is there a benefit to putting your prices on show? How do you raise prices?

6. How might location help/hinder new startups. I’m based in the North, in a small town. It’s not an affluent area and small businesses locally see even £200 as expensive for a website, so it’s tough. The closest area to me with any significant growth is Sheffield. 

7. How key is location? Do you meet with every potential client?

podcast.title: Web Design Therapy
podcast.description: This is the WEB DESIGN THERAPY. Learn the inside secrets of running a successful web design agency. You send in the questions and we answer them. Our company, We Make Websites, has been around for seven years and we’ve learnt a serious amount about running an agency - and we also have a small claim to fame for being the no.1 experts in Design, Development and Marketing in the UK on the Shopify platform. Our founders Alex and Piers will answer your questions each week on this new channel.Alex O’Byrne is a co-founder at We Make Websites, he is an international speaker on the topic of ecommerce and has spoken at Google, Digital Shoreditch and Top Drawer. Piers Thorogood is a co-founder and lead designer at WeMakeWebsites. He has built websites for companies large and small and now runs the design team at WeMakeWebsites’s London HQ.Thanks for tuning in and be sure to send all your questions to therapy@wemakewebsites.com

episodes.title: Episode 2 - Project workflow, coding standards and cats
episodes.description:
1. What are the red flags when onboarding new clients?

2. I’d like to know about your sales process, do you have salespeople? When did you bring them on? How does it work?

3. How do agencies diversify their client base? And, how do you cope when one big client tries to monopolise all your resources?

4. Do you / at what point did you start introducing / enforcing “style guides” for written code?

5. Would love a walk through your general client workflow - how you plan and schedule a client project, and how you deliver on it.

6. How do you find good office space? How important is a good office?

 

DO YOU HAVE A QUESTION TO ASK? 
EMAIL US: therapy@wemakewebsites.com

podcast.title: Web Design Therapy

Our company, We Make Websites, has been around for seven years and we’ve learnt a serious amount about running an agency - and we also have a small claim to fame for being the no.1 experts in Design, Development and Marketing in the UK on the Shopify platform. Our founders Alex and Piers will answer your questions each week on this new channel.Alex O’Byrne is a co-founder at We Make Websites, he is an international speaker on the topic of ecommerce and has spoken at Google, Digital Shoreditch and Top Drawer. Piers Thorogood is a co-founder and lead designer at WeMakeWebsites. He has built websites for companies large and small and now runs the design team at WeMakeWebsites’s London HQ.Thanks for tuning in and be sure to send all your questions to therapy@wemakewebsites.com

episodes.title: Episode 1 - Being a salesperson, late payments and Mcvities biscuits
episodes.description:
1. I have a frequent problem where clients change their mind or ask for new features during the build of a site. I end up either making the changes for free, or pissing off the client by pushing back. How do you guys deal with that?

2. I'm currently freelancing, but want to start and agency. What's your best piece of advice for getting started?

3. At the moment, all of my clients come through word of mouth, which is great, but I don't want to rely on it. How can I generate more business?

4. My web agency builds any and every type of website. I notice you guys specialise in e-commerce and, more specifically, Shopify - what made you do that and would you recommend it?

5. How do you guys deal with clients not paying / paying late?

6. I'm a designer and the most irritating part of my job is when clients' feedback ends up butchering my designs. What's the best way to stop this?

DO YOU HAVE A QUESTION TO ASK? 
EMAIL US: therapy@wemakewebsites.com
